page.lettertext:
fol.157r
Belgia
Belgia 1591 5 Junij
It may please yo
r
good L. to be advertised,
that folowing suche instruction, as I receaved
from her Ma
tie
and likewise from yo
r
L. by
12/21 Maij
letters of
e 12 and 21 of May, w
ch
I recea-
ved, as I have formerly signified,
e 1 of this
moneth, I have notified heere unto
e states,
what her Hig
nes
doth require. The letter sent
hither was only to this Councel, w
ch
M
r
Caron
conveied, and I had from yo
r
L.
e tr
a
script
of it. The body of
e Councel doth continewe, at
e Campe, but yet there were two of them heere,
by whome
e letter was opened and imparted
to
e states. The letter contening two
principal pointes, an answear to
e Councel
in
e affaires of
Ostend,
and a declaration of
Ostend
suche causes, as doe move her Ma
tie
to just offense
for
e abuse of their trafficke. I have dealt
traffick
w
t
e states in
e seconde point only, alleaging
those reasons that yo
r
L. had sette downe: w
ch
I have also exhibited in writing unto them.
They doe in this, as their maner is commonly in
maters of importance. They will yelde no ans-
wear at
e first, but consult upon it. Never-
theles my proposition being made unto them
e
2 of this moneth, they sent yesterday their
Greffier,
to lett me understande, that they will
presently take in hand
e Answear w
ch
was made
to their Deputies in England, and will not leave
answer to be
made
it till suche time, as they have made that conclu-
sion, w
ch
their state will permitte. They cast
a great fault upon their
marchants,
whome they
can not, as they say, so easely induce, as perhaps
a stranger would conjecture, to agree to a
certaine order, and admitte a
limitation in
the course of their trafficke. And forasmuche
as I have charged them not only in general
fol.157v
with
e transportation of victuals and munition
to
e Enemies contrey, but have particularly pro-
ceeded to
e nomination of suche masters and
marchants, as have in that behalf offended:
according to those specialties w
ch
yo
r
L. sent
unto me: they doe signifie therunto, that the
most of those complaintes were fully answea-
red by their Deputies, at their being in England:
and they hope by their letters, to content her Hig
nes
for
e rest. Moreover for
at
ei are blamed
for
e cariadge of
provision to
e Liguers
vi
s
to
e leagers
in Fr
a
ce
in France, they willed their Greffier to de-
clare unto me, that they have already written
to
e
kinge to this effect
, That in case his
f
r
K
y
gs edict
Ma
tie
will strictly interdict, by a generall
prohibition to all men, of what nation soever, to
use any suche trade to
e aide of those rebels,
making his restraint in suche sort, as her Ma
tie
hath done in England, they will willingly then
concurre in making
e like placart, and ob-
serve it effectually. This is as muche as
e Greffier signified, promising only further
a speedy resolution: for w
ch
I will solicite
and insist so earnestly, as considering howe
often they have bin dealt w
t
all before, in the
self same cause, I hope they will surcease their
tedious delaye. I have touched them for it,
both to him and before, aswell in publicke as
privat conference, and w
t
as muche libertie
of speeche, as I might well w
t
good maner.
It should seeme by those letters, w
ch
I receaved
from her Ma
tie
and likewise from yo
r
L. it was
expected from me, that I should have informe
d
howe
e states had accepted of
at order of
trafficke, w
ch
was proposed by her Ma
tie
[to their]
Deputies in England. Howbeit I assure y
[o
r
L.]
fol.158r
Belgia: 1591: June
I had never no suche charge, to prosecute those
maters, but only at suche time, as I and M
r
Wilkes were joined in commission. So it was
at w
t
yo
r
L. letter of
e
23 of Feb last
, I
23 Feb
r
receaved an abridgement of
e whole negotiation
w
t
e Deputies in England,
w
t
e answear of
my LL. to all their propositions. But
withall
yo
w
signified, that it was but to make me ac-
quainted w
t
e course that had bin held w
t
the
states in those affaires, to
e end that if any
occasion should falle out, in their meetinges or
otherwise, to treat of any of those pointes, I might
knowe her Hig
nes
inclination, and conforme my self
accordingly. And seing it was a mater, where
in their lingering did bring unto themselves the
greatest prejudice, I thought it not fitte, to
urge it of my self, not being otherwise required.
As concerning those affaires that touche
ostend
e Governor of Ostend, because they properly be-
long to
e Councel of state, w
ch
is absent at this
present, and because her Ma
ties
letter is an answear
chiefly unto them, I can use no c
o
ference w
t
them,
untill I come unto
e Campe. For if I finde by
the states, that their deliberation will be ended
in any short time, I will attend in this place,
untill I may receave it: otherwise I will take
some other order, to have it sent unto me, and
depart w
t
in these 3 daies. For I knowe my
presence w
t
e Councell, who have sent for me
often, will be more to
e advantage of her Ma
ties
service. I thinke it very needefull to
advertise yo
r
L. that wheras her Hig
nes
alleageth
in her letter
to this Councel, that aswell they, as
e states doe
offend continually, in aiding
e Enemie w
t
victuals
and warlicke provision, for their owne privat
lucre: suche heere of
e councel, to whome
at letter
fol.158v
Belgia: 1591: June
was delivered, were deepely displeased upon the
reading of that clause:
for that in
e college of
e
stat
M
r
c
h
co
u
sell
states there are divers
marchants
but there are
none of
e Councel,
at doth use any trafficke.
But I have signified heere unto them,
at
e cause
of
at erro
r
is wholy in
e states,
who by often
intermedling in suche causes as belong to
e Councel
of state, have made so great a confusion in their
government, as men that are heere inhabitants come
daily to one assembly in steede of an other, not
knowing in their buisnes, to whome to addresse
themselves: and therfore easely her Ma
tie
might
mistake
e Councel of state for
e General states,
among whome there were some,
at were openly
noted to be both marchants, and chief supporters
of those unlawfull traffickes. The
dislike
at is growen between
e Councel of state,
ost
e
d / S
r
Edward Nor
r
and
e Governor of ostend doth increase every
day: and as by former letters I have certi-
fied yo
r
L. unles they may be obeied, I am
very muche afraide, it will breede an incon-
venience. For mine owne part I protest unto
yo
r
L. as I desire to be continued in her Ma
ties
favo
r
, I have done my uttermost endevor, to
procure a toleration of his
present proceedinges,
but they are bent so muche against it, as there
is no dealing by any persuasion. The states
of Zeland, as yo
r
L. hath written, would
not willingly retene
e contrey of Flanders in
Zell
a
d
contribution, but hold it all as Enemie, preten-
ding therin a publicke commoditie: w
ch
hath bin
often debated in
e Councel of state, as I have
certified heeretofore
e reasons of bothe sides: but
e Councel of state would never yelde unto it
nevertheles they have openly declared, that
[they]
would rather agree to have no contributi
o
[.]
they would be ruled by
e Governo
r
in
[.]
fol.159r
Belgia: 1591: June
sition of the mony. I neede not certifie all
occasions, for whiche they stand in this sort ill
affected against him. For I see their earnestnes
is suche, as they themselves will spare no paines
in making informac
o
n. Whiche whether they have
done already, as they determined fortnight sins,
or will take some ocasion upon her Ma
ties
last
letter, I beseeche yo
r
L. to advise upon it, that
somwhat may ensewe for
e ending of this troble,
whiche I see in time may growe prejudiciall to
a good correspondence, w
t
out any benefit to her
Ma
tie
. This contrey, to my understanding,
is nowe in
e highe way of prosperitie,
e enemie
being weaker, and their owne forces greater, then
they have bin of a longe time. And likewise
their turnes, as they say themselves, were never
better served, then they are at this present, by those
of o
r
nation: towardes whome their affection is
amended very muche: and if it could be more
augmented, and
e people drawen by good meanes,
to respect w
t
more duty her Ma
ties
autoritie, I
doe certainly thinke, to speake it w
t
submission to
yo
r
L. correction, it would prove a singular
securitie against whatsoever may be feared, of
their starting to
e Frenche, or according with the
Spaniard. The last point of her
Ma
ties
letter is for moving this Councel to restore
Charles Ch
a
b
Charles Chamberlaine
to
e place of Provost Mar-
shall in Berghen Up Zome. To acquaint yo
r
L.
w
t
e cause,
e said Chamberlaine had enjoied
that rowme some time by appointment of
e L.
Willughby then Governo
r
of Berghen, but was
never chosen unto it, nor acknowledged as Provost
by the Councel of state, to whome
e election in
at
office doth belong in these contreis. Wherupon S
r
Thomas Morgan comming after to
at government, ac-
counted that place as voide, and recommended
fol.159v
Belgia: 1591: June
therunto one John Crooke, of whome
e Councel made
choise, and gave him a commission w
t
instructions,
whiche he hath exercised these two yeres: in all w
ch
time I can not understand, that any complaint
hath come against him. And for certaine it is so
contrary to
e custome of these men, to displace
any man, that is placed by themselves, w
t
out just
occasion, and to seeme to acknowledge that they
have wronged
e other, as there will come nothing
but dislike of any suche proposal. At
the writing hereof I receaved yo
r
L. letter of
the 7 of
e last moneth, w
t
licence from her
7 Maij for d
o
kyrk
Ma
tie
to proceede in that plotte, w
ch
was propoun-
ded about
Dunkerke,
w
t
e privitie of Count
Maurice.
As yet I have not seene the Captaine
Vanderbrooke
and
e parties are not heere, that
were dealers w
t
me in
e first discoverie. But
I will use suche conference w
t
e
Governo
r
of Flushing
, being willed by her Ma
tie
to break
this mater w
t
e Count, as her Hig
nes
intention
shall be thorowly accomplished. Howbeit
e
soonest
season
for
e execution of
e enterprise, will
october
be in October, when
e nightes beginne to leng-
then. M
r
Gilpin is come from
Amsterdame, where
e shipper was arrived that
brought
e two Englishe out of Spaine: but the
winde being contrary, he could not yet enter w
t
his shippe into
e haven. M
r
Gilpin suspecting
that he in person might be knowen to
e shipper, d
id
not speake himself unto him, but imploied an ho-
nest and sufficient person, to whome
e shipper
who is also accounted a right honest man, con-
fessed at first that he had suche
kinde of booke
s
w
ch
he promised to shewe
, when his shippe w[.]
wryt
y
gs in
e
ship of Amsterd
a
in: but of those two Englishe men, that were [.]
passengers, it seemed he could not speake t[.]
fol.160r
Belgia: 1591: June
ill. There is order taken that
e forsaid party,
shall be attendant upon
e shipper, and effect the
mater by meanes of
Snowdens letters,
and by
Snowd
e
s l
re
s
faire speeche. Otherwise if
e shipper will be fro-
ward, I have written certaine letters, w
ch
the
party may
be
deliver, to
e Admiraltie and
Burgmasters of Amsterdame, to assist him with
autoritie. The bearer herof M
r
Lamb
t
Lambert
hath bin both present himself, and also
a doer, both at
Zutphen
and
Deventer:
for w
ch
I knowe for those actions, to signifie more unto
yo
w
, were but to lengthen my letter, and to
troble yo
r
L. It is nowe in consultation
to what place they shall marche, for their next
exploit.
Holland and Utrecht
are for
Neume-
ghen and
Steenwicke: but
Count
William
and those of
Frise are bent
towardes
Groeninghen
,
for whiche they doe challenge
e last yeres pro-
mise. There is very great
hope
both of
Nieumeghen
and
Steenwicke, if
e victorie
be folowed.
Groeninghen notwitstanding is of greater conse-
quence. Only this is nowe objected, that by
drawing all o
r
forces as farre as Groeninghen,
and leaving these quarters unprovided of succo
rs
,
to relieve any place
at the Enemie may attempt,
were to putt all
e contrey in over great hasard.
In whiche respect they of
Holland are earnest
,
to keepe their forces neerer home, till the Ene-
mies purpose may be thorowly knowen: whiche,
as nowe it is bruited, doth provide for
Tertol
or
e Land of Tergoes
. Nevertheles I had
some speeche with
Count Maurice
, before his going
from hens, about
e enterprise
of Groeninghen,
whome I found
v ery
forward, and
thorowly resolved, not to
Leese
e opportunitie of doing somwhat there this
sommer; but sooner or later as occasions are presented.
fol.160v
Belgia: 1591: June
Of
e Englishe Captaines
at served at Deventer,
it was reported at first that Cap
t
Browne was
slaine: w
ch
is nowe fallen out to be Cap
t
Me-
thikerke.
And thus beseeching yo
r
L. to
make relation to her Ma
tie
of suche pointes of
my letter,
as
are expected from me, I take my
humble leave. From
e Hage.
June 5 1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley.
